ReviewList.Text: Creating Unforgettable Characters is a wonderful tool for writers because it goes into details about the amount of backstory that is appropriate and how to set it up and the traits and characteristics that should breathe life into the characters.  This book has been extremely helpful to me and I have read it three times.

This book is geared mainly for screenwriting, but it can be useful for novelists and short story writers as well.  Linda Seger discusses character backstory, relationships with supporting characters, dialogue, and so on.  Plus, there are interviews with today's leading writers across the  spectrum.  Her narrative is clear and easy to understand, with plenty of  examples of both good and bad writing.  Even though I'm not a screenwriter,  I found this book very useful and entertaining.

This is one of the finest books I've ever read on the crafting of fiction.  It's not just for screenwriters, but also for those who develop any form  of creative writing.  Along with 'Making a Good Script Great', I'd highly  recommend Dr. Seger's books as a terrific asset to any fiction writer's  shelf.

Author.Name: Myra
Author.Location: Video trainer in Salt Lake City, Utah, USA

ReviewList.Text: Thankyou for this book.  I am a screen and television writer.  In the last six months it has been an enormous pleasure to first discover Linda Segers books and then to sit under her teaching in person and hear her lecture this past Feb. in Toronto, Ont. when she taught at the Guilds.  Her  insights, intuitive nature, her ability and grasp of story ..both through  book and in person is a highly trained gift and a guide to those of us  finding our way in the world of story.  I strongly recommend any work she  does in book form or lecture and look forward to reading more from her.

Dr. Seger's book focuses on one of the most enjoyable and also one of the most difficult jobs of a storyteller: creating strong, believable, "one of a kind" characters. She shows you how to avoid the  pitfalls of stereotyping, how to make even minor characters interesting,  and how to add believable complexity. I think any writer who works with  original characters would benefit from this book. Dr. Seger gives clear  examples and is easy to understand without talking down to the reader. It  is the kind of book you find yourself using over and over.

I met Linda Seger several years ago when she lived in Venice, CA. and was making her living as a script consultant.  I had read an L.A. Times article about her work and thought she might be able to help me become a better screenwriter.  At the time, I was part of a writer's group that was hosted by Sam Locke, who had come to Hollywood after having had a successful Broadway play, "Fair Game" starring Ellen Burstyn.  I bought Linda's book.  I found it to be generic.  I paid her to read a script that I was working on about Navy SEALs (before the genre became popular) and to give me a story analysis.  Apparently, she had done her Ph.D. dissertation on linear screenplay structure.  I asked Linda if she was aware of "Pulp Fiction", by Quentin Tarantino which had a unique circular story structure.  Seger wasn't aware of it.  Her orientation was simply old school.  It is helpful when you interact with a writer who is open to new possibilities.  For instance, I found Amy Deardon who wrote "The Story Template" to be very receptive to my comments about how to simplify her in-depth analysis of why we respond to well-crafted stories (they all have a similar, definable structure).  Some writers are able to write about their craft.  Linda has no screenwriting credits.  Her 'how to' books are based on theory, not experience.  Linda now lives Colorado.

It's a decent book when it comes to learning about building character. Some of its insights are sort of common knowledge where as other can be found in superior script books that don't focus exclusively on character (McKee's "Story", Trottier's "Screenwriter's Bible"). The book is from 1990 so many of the television references aren fairly dated. Seger also has a tendency to let quotes from other writers do all of the heavy lifting. The book would strengthened if Seger infused some flavor and a voice of her own but instead the pros are fairly dry. A decent supplemental book on screenwriting.
Linda Seger gives screenwriters the tools to write vivid, well developed characters with this book.  I recommend it to all my screenwriting students!  Marisa D'Vari, author, Script Magic.

Linda did a good job here in brewing up all the bits of advice dreaded by any writer: finding the voice, writing with power and energy, beginnings, middles and ends... So at the end (if you make it so far) this book leaves you dizzy and if you're out for hands-on advice, go get yourself something else. What I find particularly annoying are the endless quotations of writers, Linda thinks are important and famous, but who infact are - well - not so important and not so famous and serve up a lot of not so great platitudes. So why 2 stars? If you don't lose your patience, you may be lucky enough to find some bits you can actually implement and need, such as her examples on subtext.

I will agree with the many reviews that said this book was full of a lot of basics, but it is still a good reference and worth reading. While some of the information I scanned, other parts gave me fresh ideas. Perhaps it made the difference that many of the works she referred to were books, shows or movies I was familiar with. Either way, I made some highlights on my weaker areas so I can refer occasionally back to it to make sure I am becoming stronger and not overlooking laziness.

"Creating Unforgettable Characters" is a great reference and educational book for writing full, believable characters.  I'm in the process of developing characters for a novel and discovering that this book is an essential tool.  It is well written so that anyone can understand and apply the information.  I highly recommend this book to any novelist or screenwriter who is desiring to enrich their characters.  Thank you. Dena
